title: Same quantity for helium and argon atoms

content.description: The figure shows a cylindrical tube that is closed at both ends. There is a piston in the tube that can slide with negligible friction and is attached to the left end of the tube by a spring. The left half of the tube contains a mixture of one mole of atomic helium gas (with mass <math alttext="4 atomic mass units" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>amu</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>) and one mole of atomic argon gas (with mass <math alttext="40 atomic mass units" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>40</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>amu</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>). The right half of the tube contains a vacuum. Initially, the gas mixture is in thermal equilibrium with the surroundings and the piston is in the center of the tube.
content.question: Which of the following is the same for the helium and argon atoms?

choices.label: The number of collisions per second between atoms and the piston
The average speed of the atoms
The average kinetic energy of the atoms
The average magnitude of the momentum of the atoms

content.answer: The average kinetic energy of the atoms
